text: It's DUSK. The DIN of night insects is all around. We're trudging along a rutted dirt road toward a glow on the horizon...

location: BALL FIELD, OGDEN MARSH HIGH SCHOOL, KANSAS

text: A baseball game being played under the lights behind the local high school. STUDENTS, FACULTY, TOWNSPEOPLE fill th wooden bleachers. It's the regional playoffs. Everybody i here. The MAYOR, the PASTOR, the FIRE CHIEF, all the VIPs small town has to offer. Even the town sheriff has turned up for the end of the ga He parks his cruiser in the overflow lot and comes down t hill to the diamond, keys jangling on his belt beside a holstered gun he never uses. DAVID DUTTON. Easy-going. Second-generation sheriff. Pillar of the community. Trading a dozen hellos, clapping some old timer on the shoulder, giving the coach a thumbs-up about the score, h comes around the backstop to the little CONCESSIONS TRAIL Sets his hat on the counter. Handsome. Grinning with hometown pride.
They're playin' well, Kev, they're playin' awful damn well. Win this one they could have a shot. (to Vendor's wife in b.g.) Hey Linda. She nods hi. The VENDOR pours him a cup of coffee, on the house.
Fryeburg's tough. They'd be next.
(smile fades) Fryeburg, yeah. Shit. Well, one at a time, one at a time... David heads off, coffee in hand.
Thanks, Kev. David leans on the sideline fence, sipping his coffee, watching the game. The star pitcher blows a fastball past the batter. David lets out a howl.
Scotty McLeod! You throw like you drive, son, too damn fast! He puts down his coffee so he can applaud the strikeout w both hands then picks it up again and takes another sip.

Look alive, fellas! Deano, watch the squeeze! No one has yet noticed the DARK FIGURE walking out of the shadowy woods beyond the outfield. Weaving like a drunkar he walks right onto the playing field, oblivious to the g Aman of fifty. Local pig farmer. His name is RORY HAMILL. He is carrying a SHOTGUN. Heads turn, mouths falling open in the bleachers and dugo everybody staring in collective disbelief. It's surreal, guy with a gun just walked past Petey Jenkins in left fie
Rory, what in God -- ? David drops his coffee and jumps the fence, goes out acro the diamond to intercept him, hollering, waving his hands
Rory, whoa, Rory, Rory, whoa, whoa, whoa! Rory Hamill gets as far as the infield before David, cutt in front of him now, keeping ten feet of distance, finall gets his attention.
Rory stops, glassy-eyed, head lolling sickly to one side. David keeps his gun holstered, tries to reason with him. players frozen at their positions on the field.

The hell you doing, Rore? Hunh? Got a ball game going on here. We're playing ball, you come out here with a gun? The goddamn hell you doing? Rory casts a glance around the field. A dizzying number o faces out there. All eyes on him. He wobbles a little, catches himself.

Lay it down, Rory, you're drunk. His gaze floats back to David and it's different than it a moment ago. Harder. Deadly. David is not a man easily spooked, but that look sends a chill right through him.

Lay it down! Rory takes a wavering step forward. David draws his weapo Rory responds in kind, leveling his. People gasp. David retreats a step. Might be the first time in his life he's had a gun pointed at him by someone ready to use it.

Don't do it, Rory! Don't you do it! Rory brings his eye to the sights, draws back on the trig and - BANG! - David shoots first. A single shot, but a deadly one. Rory Hamill collapses midfield. SCREAMS from the bleachers and SOBS in the aftersilence a the whole town registers the strange human tragedy that j played out under the lights behind the high school. A body facedown in the grass behind the pitcher's mound, Sheriff David Dutton standing over it, astonished, holdin his hand the gun he never uses. FADE TO BLACK.
The stillness of prairie grass in the blue hush before da Beyond it, a traditional white clapboard house with an ol barn that needs painting.
A young woman awakens to find her husband's side of the b empty. Runs a hand over the sheet, checking for body warm It's cold. Strange. She puts on a robe.
Comes downstairs in the darkened house.
Babe...? No reply. Worried, she comes down the hall into the -

No sign of him. She startles at a movement behind her. The SCREEN DOOR, creaking back and forth in a draft. She comes over to close it and sees, through the screen, husband sitting alone outside in the shadowy dawn.

It's David out here, second-guessing himself. His wife JU sits down quietly beside him, come to lend a sympathetic If he is one pillar of the community, she is the other, a local standout who came back from med school to be the to doctor.
He didn’t give me a choice. Judy shakes her head in reassurance of that fact. Takes h hand for moral support. Looks to the distance, reflecting

You asked me once when we first got together if I thought less of you for staying here after high school and following in your dad’s footsteps. I want you to know something. People like you, the ones that stay, are the reason why people like me come back. David meets her gaze, heartened by that, and then places hand gently, tellingly, on her midsection.
You should be sleeping.
David's cruiser travels through the lonesome countryside.

Turns in the drive of a rundown farmhouse on the outskirt town. Poorest family in Ogden Marsh. Parking, getting out David meets eyes with two boys feeding pigs behind the ba JAKE and CURT HAMILL. Rory's teenage sons. Tough kids, bu they've both been crying. Before David can say anything t turn coldly away. He goes up the front steps to the house. Takes off his h knocks. The door opens to reveal Rory's widow. PEGGY HAMILL. Awkward is an understatement. David is the last person she expected to see on her doorstep this morning.

Peggy, I... (sudden loss for words) I knew what I was gonna say before I got here... (then) I'm real sorry, Peg. I liked Rory, I liked him a lot. Whatever resentment she might have harbored is defused by David's simple decency. Looking him in the face, she just crumbles. It's heartbreaking.

(in heaving sobs) What was he doin'? What was he doin'? David holds her, the only thing keeping her upright. And see them from a distance, together in their anguish, the sheriff and the wife he made a widow.

A lone street light flashes yellow on Main Street. It wil do that all day. An A & P, a post office, a bank. No frills. No artifice. Like the people that live here. David's cruiser pulls up outside C. R. Finley Funeral Hom which doubles as the town morgue.
MORTICIAN CHARLES FINLEY and the TOWN PASTOR are discussi funeral arrangements in the dimly-lit foyer. David enters and they go silent, unintentionally.
Pastor, Charlie...

(to Finley in parting) I'll talk to the family, see if that schedule suits them. The Pastor pats David's arm as he exits, a gesture of solidarity. David comes over to Finley. An odd man whose bony features reflect the grim solitude of his trade.
Medical examiner still here?
Was a minute ago.
Charlie, whatever the costs are for the funeral, bill comes to me, all right? Finley nods okay. David heads for the back.

TIP OF A PEN writes: "Aorta ruptured - fatal wound: gunshot..." The MEDICAL EXAMINER, balding, bespectacled, finishing hi autopsy notes. David walks over. A body sheeted in plasti on the autopsy table. Tag on the toe: HAMILL, RORY C.
Just wanted to get his blood- alcohol, put in my report.
Zero-point-zero.
Come again?
Zero-point—-
I heard what you said. Stacy, that's not right, he was drunk. The Examiner shakes his head. Collects his things to go.

Checked it twice. Rory was a drinker, but not last night. He exits. David, baffled, peels back the sheet and studie the corpse like it might offer clues. But there is only t grim reality of death. The tell-tale Y-shaped incision sutured shut across the torso. And the small black hole his bullet made.

Small, functional. David's lone deputy is fielding phone calls in the common area. DEPUTY RUSSELL. Young. Capable. Built like a linebacker. He'd be sheriff if David weren't around but his loyalty is absolute.
(into phone) I can’t answer that - look, like I said, you'll have to talk to Sheriff Dutton, try back later. David enters as he hangs up.
Hey.
Russ. David goes into his office. Sorts through the mail on his desk. Russell follows, only as far as the doorway, stands there for a moment gauging the climate.
Some fuckin' ball game, huh. David sits down, nods.
Yeah.
Humble brick building with a sign out front. Home of the wildcats.
So you all saw something last night I sure wish you hadn't...
David, before a microphone, addressing the STUDENTS in general assembly. SCHOOL OFFICIALS looking on.
..-Hard to make sense of it, even for me. Talk to your teachers, talk to me if you want... The SEA OF YOUNG FACES, some visibly upset, some visibly
..--We don’t have all the answers, but we’re here to help.
Post assembly, David walks down the hall with the PRINCIP Students swarm past back to class. Flirting. Talking on cell phones. Life returning to normal.
Wasn't so long ago you were roaming these halls. That hellraiser turned into a sheriff somehow. And a fine one. (then) Your mom and dad still liking Florida okay?
Yeah. Dad swore he wouldn't last a month down there. Then he saw the golf courses. They come past a teacher who can’t unlock his classroom d Mid-forties. Shirt and tie. Native Kansan. BILL FARNUM.
Bill...?
I give up. They rekey the locks this weekend? Maybe it’s jammed... Farnum tugs on the door, mystified. But no one is more mystified than David and the Principal.

Bill, you don’t - you retired, five years ago. Farnum looks at them in utter confusion. Rubs his nose an his finger comes back with a BLOODY SMUDGE on it. The Principal offers a handkerchief as he walks Farnum away, gesturing to David ‘I got it’.
Hit your head or something? Come on, why don’t you sit down in my office. David watches them go, the tide of students flowing past

David stands at the fence staring at the empty field, dismayed. TWO PLANES fly past high overhead. Side by side a half mi apart. David glances up, barely taking notice. Sees the coffee c he dropped is still lying there in the grass. Tosses it i the trash can before heading up the hill to his cruiser.

We're flying over the prairie at ten thousand feet. Beautiful view. Farms. Open fields. A sudden burst of HIG SPEED PHOTOGRAPHS rips the entire county into a GRID OF FREEZE FRAMES. EXT. TOWN CENTER —- SUNDOWN Small town life. Families in the local pizza joint. Guy washing his truck. Woman walking her dog on an empty road
A single-story brick-and-mortar building with two cars in lot.
Judy, in a traditional white doctor's coat, gives a tetan shot to a boy with a bandaged foot. She has a gentle touc
(finished) Wasn’t too bad, was it? The boy shakes his head. He and his mother stand to go.
(musses boy's hair) Adventure on, young man, but keep an eye out for...?
Rusty nails.
Rusty nails. (to mother) Take care, Dana. Let me know if there’s any swelling.  10.

Typical slow night. Judy is updating records with her par time office helper BECCA DARLING. Seventeen. Pretty. Loca honor student. NURSE VIOLET, town gossip, also the clinic receptionist, wanders over, bored, buffing her nails.
Started talking about names yet?
Not yet.
If it’s a girl, I like Beatrice. If it’s a boy, Morton. Knew a Morton once, ‘course we all called him Morty, maybe you should just go with Morty.
(endearing, not poking fun) Thanks, Violet, I'll put those on the list. Becca’s cell phone CHIRPS. She checks the message, keys i quick reply and resumes work, the entire exchange lasting seconds.
Okay if I leave a little early tonight? Judy, playing, scans the empty waiting room.
Hmmm, how’s our staff to patient ratio? I think you’re good. Everything all right?
Yeah. Casey Strout’s having some people over.
Algebra?
Yep. Math party.
My husband excelled at math in high school.  11. Becca smiles. Then:
Oh, by the way, he was really cool at assembly today.
Thanks.
It’s so scary to think what would've happened if he hadn’t been there the other night. Judy nods her agreement.
Sometimes you just get lucky like that.

GIANT WET TONGUES licking something, licking each other i the process. A disturbing image, but only in close-up... DAIRY COWS at a salt lick. Bill Farnum stands in the corral watching, ankle deep in briefcase in hand, blank expression. His wife DEARDRA cal to him from the house porch in the b.g., twelve-year-old NICHOLAS under her arm.
William! If he hears her, he gives no visible indication. Nicholas jogs down to the fence.
Supper’s ready. Farnum stands motionless, mesmerized. Nicholas starts to climb the fence and suddenly his father speaks, without looking, as though he was listening all along:

Be in in a sec. Nicholas heads back to the house. Bill Farnum picks his w across the muddy pen to the salt lick. Surrounded by mooi cows, he stares at it -- brick-shaped, pinkish white, dripping with bovine saliva -- then bends and gives it a disgusting lick.  12.

Crescent moon. David eyeing it from the back porch as he drinks a beer in his unbuttoned sheriff's shirt. Judy enters the kitchen behind him. Weary from the day. Sees him through the door. He holds her gaze for a moment then puts his hand under his shirt and gives it a little flutter, meaning his heart still beats for her. Makes her smile.
They kiss by the old gas stove. He brushes a lock of stra hair from her face. Married his dream.
Hungry? (she nods) What do you want?
(isn't sure) Omelet?
Sit.
Judy at the table eating her omelet. David sitting opposi polishing her wedding band on his shirt. A ritual of his.
Could drive you up to see your parents this weekend, if you want.
(smiles) Penance for your sins? He smiles a little, slips the ring back on her finger, restored to its original luster. Then, still troubled by day’s events:
Thought maybe the moon was full, I don’t know, definitely some weirdness going around. Medical examiner said he found nothing in Rory’s system.  13.
Meaning - ?
Meaning, according to the state, the man I shot was sober.
What did Peggy say?
Saw him at lunch and he seemed fine. A mystery. David left with only his instincts. And the memory:
Looked him right in the eye. He was under the influence of something. If it wasn’t alcohol it was something else.
Cows moo behind the barn. It's after midnight.

We drift through the dark hundred-year-old house, past th stairs, down the hall into the kitchen, past an old pot- bellied woodstove to the sink where we find Deardra in a nightgown looking out the window. Worried. Nicholas enter in pajamas.
Pa come in yet? Deardra shakes her head no. Her eyes never leave the wind Nicholas comes over, sees what she's staring at.

What's he doin’? Off in the distance, a COMBINE is going around in circles a field, its spotlights sweeping the prairie like a lighthouse beacon. Deardra takes a flashlight from the top of the fridge.
Wait here.  14.

House in the b.g., Deardra crosses the field, spotlights whipping across her face. Lit up like a nebula against the night sky, the billowing dust cloud gives the combine an otherworldly aura. A kill machine circling for prey, the thresher a gaping mouth of giant spinning teeth.
Up close, the noise is deafening. Deardra strides into range. Cups her hands to her mouth and calls up to the darkened cab.
William...?!
Through the windshield we can see her out there calling t us, disappearing from view as the combine goes around aga
Deardra calls once more then jogs over and climbs the met rungs to the cab. Opens the door.
William Blaine Farnum, what in heaven's -- EMPTY SEAT. A haunted pause then Deardra slides in behind the wheel. Powers down the engine. Turns off the lights.
The big machine grinds to a halt and there's a hush. Dear climbs down. Scans the dark, windswept fields.
William...? Her voice carries without answer. She turns on the flashlight and walks out into the field.
The swaying wheat. The pulse of cicadas. And then, from back at the house, a BLOOD-CURDLING SCREAM. Her son.  15.
Oh God... Deardra takes off running for the house. Frantic. Elbows flying.
Another SCREAM. Deardra, in full flight, screams back.
She crosses the field at a dead sprint. And hears somethi worse than a scream as she reaches the house. SILENCE.
She runs up the steps. In the front door.
She slows as she comes down the dark hallway. No sign of son. No sign of her husband.

Nicholas...? Silence. At the top of the stairs - A HANGING BULB SWINGS like a pendulum, casting eerie shif shadows. Deardra looks up the stairs at it. No sane perso would go up there, except a mother for a child. She climbs the stairs. Slowly, one step at a time. The ol boards CREAKING underfoot. The bulb’s shadows rocking bac and forth across her face.

Topping the stairs, she comes down the hall. Eyes wide wi fear. Shadows dancing. The light is on in the BATHROOM. Door closed. Deardra reaches out a hand, pushes the door slowly open -- CREEEEEAK -- and sees...
She looks down the hall. Darkness at the other end. Voice trembling, she calls into it.
Nicholas...?  16. As she takes her next step SOMEONE GRABS HER FROM BEHIND, throws a hand over her mouth and pulls her into the --
Nicholas. Terrified. He gestures for silence, takes his hand from Deardra's mouth. Their pale faces lit by the li coming through the crack.
What happened? What did he do? Nicholas, answer me.
He has a knife. A chill runs through Deardra.

(re: closet) We can't stay here. She cracks the door, peers out. Just then, a terrible sou FOOTSTEPS coming heavily up the stairs. And now they have no choice but the closet. Nicholas shut the door and grips the handle with both hands, praying he strong enough to keep his father out.
Bill Farnum climbs the stairs into view. He is holding a KNIFE.

Deardra helps Nicholas hold the door as Bill’s FOOTSTEPS pounding down the hallway to the closet where they STOP ABRUPTLY. Five seconds that feel like forever as Deardra and Nichol listen to Bill's HOLLOW BREATHS on the other side of the door. Both clutching the door handle, expecting it to get ripped open any second. Instead we hear a KEY go into the lock and turn - CLICK. FOOTSTEPS head back downstairs. Nicholas tries the handle couple of times before turning gravely to his mother.
He locked us in.  17.

Slinging gasoline everywhere, Farnum walks out the front door. Empties what's left in the five-gallon can onto the porch and lights it with a match. He sits down in the yard and watches it burn. Devoid of emotion. The house his grandfather built. His wife and so SCREAMING from within as blue flames scurry up the inside walls.
A RINGING PHONE wakes up David and Judy. They both reach it. His hand gets there first.
Dutton... He sits bolt upright, registering the news.
I'm coming. Jumps out of bed. Judy does the same before she even know why.
Farnums’, the whole place is going up.
Engulfed. VOLUNTEER FIREMEN hose down the trees, too late save the house or anyone inside. David's cruiser pulls up He and Judy push through the crowd of onlookers to the FI CHIEF.
Norman, did they get out?! The Fire Chief shakes his head. Judy, horrified, eyes the inferno that used to be a farmhouse.
Bill did. Begs the question, doesn't it? David takes his meaning. Crosses to where Bill Farnum sit on the back bumper of a firetruck, expressionless, hands with baling twine.
What happened, Bill?  18. Farnum doesn't respond. David squats in front of him, getting in his eyeline.
Bill, what happened here tonight? Farnum meets his gaze, glassy-eyed, remorseless.
A reckoning. Madness. David staring it in the face.
The burning house from ten thousand feet. Tiny, almost beautiful. Fire engines flashing around it like a child’s toys. A burst of FREEZE-FRAMES. The camera ZOOMS IN TIGHT Another burst.
Next morning, Russell is outside trying to placate some L REPORTERS as David talks on the phone.

Was hoping to transfer him, we’re not really equipped for this sort of thing. Okay, two o'clock. Hangs up. A haunted pause. The last forty-eight hours betraying everything he knows. He turns his gaze to Bill Farnum who sits in a stupor in a holding cell at the back the station. Russell enters.
They tell me they don't want the deputy, they want the sheriff. David gets up from his desk. Still watching Farnum.
Looked at me last night like he coulda slit my throat and barely known the difference. (turns to Russell) Same look Rory gave me. Same goddamn look. Walks out to talk to the press.  19.

Plumes of smoke rise from the ashes. A scorched brick chimney stands like a monument to the dead. David picks u charred photo. The Farnum family. He drops it, surveys th scene with dismay. A faint DRONING HUM draws his gaze skyward. Those SAME TW PLANES flying over. Side by side a half mile apart. But lower this time. David's eyes narrow with suspicion.
What're you lookin' for? And as the search planes dip below the far treeline...

A freshwater marsh on the outskirts, the town's namesake. OLD TIMER in hipwaders is dumping crayfish from wire trap into a bucket. He hears something. Straightens for a look Twenty yards away, something white is billowing like an untrimmed mainsail. He comes over for a look. Touches the material. Ripstop nylon. Billowing again, it's clear what it is... A PARACHUTE. He follows the twisted cords over a rise in the marsh to where they settle in deeper water beyond. Gives the lines tug and then staggers backwards in horror as - A HUMAN BODY floats to the surface. Hideously discolored. Bloated from decomposition.
Lord God... A MILITARY PILOT. Oxygen mask on his face.

A bodybag zipper opens to reveal the pilot's ROTTING CORP David catches a glimpse and turns away, he's seen enough. Russell gags at the stench. Even Finley, mortician of twe years, looks a little grossed out.
I'll see if there's any identification.
(exits; needing air) Yeah, do that.  20.
David and Russell cough the stench from their lungs as th cross the parking lot. Then:
Got us a pilot, where's the plane? Russell, as they reach the cruiser, recollects:
Travis King - you know Travis?
I know he's a lyin' bastard.
Said he heard something out by Hopman Bog last week. I thought he was tellin' stories again. David slows, meets Russell's gaze over the roof of the cruiser.
David, Russell and TRAVIS KING, a human rodent, motoring across the bog in a flat-bottomed aluminum boat.
Sounded like a plane you said, huh, Trav?
Yep. I gettin' paid for this?
Big plane, little plane?
I dunno, a plane, I was on the shitter. So how much I gettin'?
Travis.
Yeah.
Say that again you'll be the second person I shot this week.  21. Travis takes him at his word. David notices something up ahead. Turns the boat toward it for a better look.
Whaddaya see, chief? David indicates a spot in the woods where the tops of tre have been sheared off.

Something came real close to taking a bath. David kills the outboard and they drift in closer. A stra toxic sheen to the water in this area. Russell reaches tw fingers down for a sample. David yanks Russell's hand bac
Know what that is?
No.
Then don't touch it. David bends for a closer look. The spill has that chemica rainbow quality of gasoline. Jettisoned fuel perhaps. He scoops some into a Mason jar. Pauses as he screws on the lid.
It was a big plane.
Why's that? David straightens, oddly quiet, staring at the water.

‘Cause we're right on top of it. Off Russell's look, we rise up above them, to the height the treetops, and see what David sees - THE MURKY CONTOUR OF A MILITARY TRANSPORT PLANE submerged the water where it crashed, the boat floating directly ab
David talks on a cell phone while he and Russell unhook t boat trailer outside the corrugated-steel equipment shed.  22.

(into phone) Say, you folks missing a plane? (brow furrows) No? Well somebody oughta tell that to the pilot in our morgue. Military, yes, ma'am. Dutton. D-U- T-T-O-N. Yep, I'll be here. He pockets the phone. Stews.
Plane that size goes down and there's nothing in the paper, nothing on the news? Make any sense to you? Russell shrugs, unlocking the shed.

Depends what the payload is. It's an off-hand remark, means more to David than Russell He looks at the MASON JAR of tainted water on the hood of truck then turns a brooding stare to the north, a pattern thought taking shape.
Hopman Bog, what's that drain into?
Dwyer Creek.
Which drains into...?
Black Pond. Hey, you remember that monster catfish I --
(turns) Black Pond? Is that right?
Yeah... Russell isn't following yet.
Russ, where the hell you think we get our water from?  23.
TOPOGRAPHICAL MAP of the county on the wall. The Ogden Ma watershed shaded in blue. David barges in, asking his question on the fly. The TOWN PLANNER is eating lunch.
Which way's the water flow through town?
Nice to see you, too, Dave. Waste water or drinking?
Drinking. Town Planner unfolds a chart. A SCHEMATIC DIAGRAM OF THE TOWN'S WATER SYSTEM, his finger tracing the main pipeline
Comes in from the north, breaks east west...
Whose house does it get to first?
Most outlying. Let's see, uh... Runs his finger along a certain outlying route to a certa outlying farm. Looks up at David.
Rory Hamill. Hold on David's face.
With discreet alarm David shows Judy the water system schematic at the reception desk. Points to the second mos outlying farm.
Next house is Bill Farnum's. I mean, am I talking nonsense here or is it possible they reacted to something they drank, something in the water?  24.

If it's contaminated, if the concentration's high enough - but, David, we're drinking that same water. Everybody is. If there's something in it, we're all going to get it. David backs away, crisis on his hands.

Farnum's are a mile out, might not have made it this far yet. Tell everybody don't drink it. He runs out. Judy - the schematic in CLOSEUP - runs her finger from 'FARNUM DAIRY' across town to the pipeline's five miles from Black Pond, a plot labelled 'DUTTON FARM' She contemplates that distance, their safety buffer, then raises her gaze to the WAITING ROOM. It’s half full. There is a WOMAN sitting head slumped forward in the corner chair. Judy walks over, look of concern. Lifts the woman’s chin. The widow, Peggy Hamill, unconscious.
Peggy? Can you hear me? Peg...? Peggy's eyes flutter open partway. Pupils dilated. Barely conscious.

You need to lay down? Peggy ATTACKS without warning. Knocks Judy off her feet, tearing her blouse. It takes three guys to pull her off a subdue her as Nurse Violet helps a badly shaken Judy to h feet.

What’s gotten into her? Peggy Hamill, held down, writhing and shrieking on the fl EXT. POOL, MAYOR’S HOUSE - DAY A flabby white-bread bureaucrat saunters up the steps of in-ground pool, toweling off after a morning swim. MAYOR HOBBS.
That water's contaminated I’m Hilary goddamn Clinton.  25. David puts the jar of toxic water in his hand.
I'm shutting it down, Tom.
(eyeing jar then pool) Shit.
A MUNICIPAL WORKER muscles the wheelcrank on a high-press pipe valve, shutting off the town's water. Done, he looks at David from the hole he's in.
off.
David, driving back into town, lost in thought, RADIO PLAYING.

WKLC Kansas City. News on the hour every hour. Fire crews in Southern California continue to battle wildfires this morning -- The signal goes to STATIC. David gives the radio a glance. Tries a different station STATIC. Flips through all the stations - STATIC. Weird. And then something weirder. Out of the corner of his eye, barely seen in the blur of a passing field. Whoosh -

head_text.subj: A FIGURE IN A WHITE BIOHAZARD SUIT

text: So incongruous it takes a moment to register. What the he He slams on the brakes. Backs up, craning his neck to see what he saw. Can't see it from here. Stops the car.
Gets out and comes around the cruiser. Surveys the field. Nothing there. Nothing but prairie. David stares across i haunted, the radio in the cruiser HISSING STATIC.
David enters, dazed.  26.
Either I'm losin' it completely or I just saw a guy in a spacesuit out by Hadley Road. Russell gestures over to his shoulder to the holding cell

That makes two guys losin' it. Bill Farnum is going BERSERK back there. Smashing his hea against the wall. Tearing the cell apart. Uncontrollable rage. David, awed, steps to the windowed partition and watches. Farnum turns. His face is hideous. ONE SIDE PARALYZED LIK A STROKE VICTIM, THE OTHER IN VIOLENT SPASMS. He hurls himself at the glass - WHAM! - almost shatters it. David steps back as he goes berserk again.
Did we or did we not request a transfer to Wichita this morning? Rhetorical question. He picks up the phone. Starts to dia Toggles the receiver. Line's dead.
Yup. Russell tosses him a cell phone. David hits the first two digits then sees the viewscreen - "SEARCHING FOR SIGNAL.. tosses it back.

Even better. Russell frowns and steps outside, trying to get a connect David tries the tv. WHITE NOISE. Turns it off. Clicks the computer mouse. CANNOT FIND SERVER. Tries the police scanner. STATIC. Switches it off, smiling at the improbability.
Russell meantime can't get a signal. David steps out besi him, surveys the town from the top of the steps. His face black with foreboding.
You know what...
What?  27.
We're in trouble.

SCREECH. David's cruiser brakes to a halt at town center. He gets out. Scans Main Street. An ominous calm. The SQUEAKING of a bicycle chain turns his head. A MIDDLE-AGED WOMAN pedaling toward him on a girl's pink- tasseled banana-seat bike, singing in eerie falsetto, an hymnal.

.--All things bright and beautiful, all creatures great and small, all things wise and wonderful, The Lord God made them all... She rides past David, lost in her own world, her haunting song filling the silence. ALTERNATE POV (through SLR camera) - From a block away, a BURST OF PHOTOGRAPHS captures the woman on the bicycle, t panning to David, a second BURST captures him as he cross Main Street, still watching the woman. As the photos continue snapping, he slowly turns, sensing he's being watched, and looks straight into camera...

Tight on David's face as he stands in the center of Main Street, staring at: A BLACK CHEVY SUBURBAN WITH TINTED WINDOWS idling at the corner by the bank. Not a car that belongs to Ogden Marsh David approaches, hand drifting instinctively toward his It tears off down the road. Fantastic acceleration. David stares for a moment, baffled. As he dashes back to his cruiser to give pursuit, a panicked WOMAN jogs across the street from the pizza shop.
Sheriff, we heard something from the funeral home little while ago.
What'd you hear?
Screamin'.  28. A frozen moment. David turns his gaze to the funeral home the street. Grabs his CB handset from the cruiser. Brings it to his mouth and clicks the button. Dead.

Lizzie, run down the station, tell Russell what you just told me, tell him I need him asap. She takes off running as David heads up the street to the funeral home, unholstering his weapon for the second time three days.
Closed for business. David tries the front door. Locked. He goes around the back.
Where the bodies are brought in. David enters, nervous, g drawn. He stops and faces -
Sterile. Eerily silent. A few gurneys and unopened boxes odorless body bags and cotton shrouds in the hall.
Charlie? No reply. David comes slowly along, white-knuckled grip o his gun. The hall is lined on both sides with closed door David comes to a door, turns the knob, opens it to reveal

Stainless steel embalming tables. Sinks. Sluices. Rinse hoses dangling from the ceiling. No bodies. No Finley. David continues down the hall. Comes through a door into the front of the shop. The FUNE HOME. Pink-hued walls. Liver-colored carpet. David pushes open another door.
darkly polished. On display. David steps in, scans the room. All the caskets are open except THAT ONE. He crosses to it. With a silent two-count throws open the lid and takes aim at  29.
Empty casket. David closes it. To his immediate left -
runs the length of the wall. Coming past it to the door, David suddenly steps back and levels his gun.
behind that curtain. The tips of his shoes poking out underneath.
Charlie? No reply. But there’s definitely a man in black shoes standing there. David steps closer. Takes hold of the curtain. Whisks it open to reveal -

head_text.subj: A ROW OF MANNEQUINS IN FUNERAL SUITS AND SHOES

text: David almost puts a bullet in one. Curses under his breat Suddenly hears something. Very faint. Coming from behind him. Down the white-tiled hall he just exited... Is someone WEEPING? David cocks the hammer of his gun. Follows that FAINT MUFFLED WEEPING down the hall to a closed door. Opens it.

No sign of Finley. Just sheet-covered CORPSES on autopsy tables. The weeping HAS STOPPED. David enters. Autopsy scales hang beside the bodies. Closets and refrigerated shelves along the walls. David yanks open a closet door, gun trained, expecting to find Finley. Nothing but medical supplies. A faint WHIMPER turns his head. He stares at the FIVE COVERED BODIES.

Charlie, if that's you, say something! No reply. Gun in hand, he steps closer to the bodies. Pee back the covers one by one:  30. RORY HAMILL'S CHALK WHITE CORPSE. THE DECOMPOSING PILOT. DEARDRA FARNUM'S CHARRED CORPSE. HER SON'S. David stares at the LAST COVERED BODY. We can see the outline of a face. The sheet expands and contracts at the nostrils. Slightly. As if from breath.
Charlie? No answer. Gun levelled, David takes the edge of the shee whisks it back to find -
Weeping through sutured eyelids. The sutures on one eye h loosened, a ghastly eye peers out through the slit. His nostrils and lips are sewn shut, arms and legs bound to t table with gauze.

Jim - ?! The Pastor goes into violent CONVULSIONS. David grabs a p of surgical scissors from a tray and, pinning the writhin body with one hand, cuts the sutures sealing the mouth. The Pastor's lips come apart like a deep fleshy wound, hi convulsions subsiding only because death is imminent. In last tortured breath:

Behind... you... What? David turns. WHIRRRR!! - THE BLADE OF A BONE SAW coming right at his f Finley swinging it at arm's length with psychotic calm. David goes down and Finley pounces, driving the blade at throat. David catches Finley's wrists, barely keeping the saw at bay, forces the spinning blade against the leg of autopsy table. SPARKS FLY as it cuts into the steel. Finley counters. Finding his knees, he brings the saw abo his head for a final plunge. But David catches him with a thrusting kick to the gut. Sends Finley crashing into the storage cabinets.  31. As he jumps up for more - BANG! - David shoots him. Finle falls in a heap. But in death he has launched perhaps his most lethal attack, dropping the SAW. Locked in the 'on' position, it COMES SKIP-BOUNCING ACROS THE FLOOR AT DAVID, propelled by the spinning blade. Davi scrambles backwards on his haunches, but can't outrun it. Just as it's about to hit him in the face -

stomps on the saw's cord, leashing it like a wild dog. Th deadly instrument hops and skips around at the end of its tether, inches from David's face. Until - Russell, owner of the boot, yanks the plug from the wall. comes over, helps David to his feet. And only then sees t Pastor's sad fate.
Christ almighty. A DEAD EYE staring back at them through the sutured slit.
Emergency town meeting. Worried TOWNSFOLK abound. David a Judy trying to manage everyone's fear and anger.
What are we supposed to drink while the water’s turned off?
The A & P has plenty of bottled. Bruce’s agreed to sell it at cost till we work out another source. Thanks again, Bruce. The A & P Manager nods.
And it just so happens while all this is going on none of the phones are working?
I know, Nathan. Russell’s on his way to Wichita right now, see if we can get some answers.
Where the hell's Mayor Hobbs?  32.
Hightailin' it to Kentucky.
(shock and disgust) What - ?
Saw him on the way out of town. Fat bastard practically ran me over. The kid’s mom swats him for talking like that. David and Judy exchanging a look about Hobbs. De facto town leaders
So whoever drank it's gonna go the way of Rory and Bill? I drank it. My wife drank it. My kids.

We don't know that it's going to affect everybody the same, everybody's body reacts a little diff -- EERIE LAUGHTER cuts her off. A woman in the back. Horn- rimmed glasses. Ten-dollar wig. Going red in the face she laughing so hard. It's creepy, she can't stop. Everybody just stares as this demented old lady laughs and laughs.
A sheriff department PICKUP speeds down the fog-cloaked highway toward Wichita.
Russell humming along at eighty miles an hour. Checks his radio. STATIC. Turns it off. Suddenly, FOUR DEAFENING POP
A SPIKE STRIP lying across the road. The truck fishtails of control, wobbling violently on its rims, threatening t roll...
Russell struggles, teeth-clenched, not to let it.  33.
Shit! Ruptured treads fly off. The pickup careens off the shoul and slams to a stop in an irrigation ditch.
Russell has barely righted himself when he’s pulled from truck by a DOZEN SOLDIERS IN BIOHAZARD SUITS. Thrown against the hood, M-16s in his face, Russell’s astonishme is almost comical.
Whoa.
Meanwhile David and Judy. Tense words in the kitchen.
Maybe you should go stay with your parents for a while.
Maybe you should go stay with my parents.
Look, this isn't --
No, David, you're not the only one with responsibilities here, half these people are my -- Sees something out the kitchen window. It scares her.
What? What was it?
(isn't sure) Shadow. David grabs his gun and goes out.
David stands at the edge of the property, eyeing the back field. It's eerily still.
Somebody there?!  34. Silence. Turning, he sees the light is on inside the

He walks over, pushes open the door with the gun muzzle. he peeks warily inside -- LAWN TOOLS CLATTER NOISILY to the floor. Scares the hell out him. David switches off the light and then hears GLAS SHATTER inside the house.
Who are you?! Who are you?!
He crosses the yard at a sprint, kicks open the screen do
And sees THREE SOLDIERS IN BIOHAZARD SUITS forcibly escor Judy to the front door. David lunges into the fray, gun outstretched.

What the fu--?! Get off her!! His heroics are short-lived. Grabbed, spun, put ina chokehold, he is disarmed and dragged out the door by the suited intruders. It's over in two seconds flat - chillin the ease with which he is subdued.
They wrestle Judy aboard an idling SCHOOL BUS. David behi her, still resisting, choked blue in the face.
Where are you taking us?!

Hurtling along under armed guard, David and Judy see shoc images out the windows. FAMILIES BEING PULLED FROM EVERY HOUSE IN SIGHT. The entire town being corralled onto buse like pigs off to slaughter.

location: BALL FIELD, OGDEN MARSH HIGH SCHOOL

text: ALL THE TOWNSPEOPLE stand in lines under the lights. Stunned. No one saw this coming. Raised ten feet and topp with razor wire, the fence is patrolled by armed guards i hazmat suits. A recorded message plays over the field's tinny P.A. system:  35.

...Please remain calm and do not interfere with the work of the examiners. Information will be provided to you as it becomes available. Thank you for your cooperation... Repeating ad infinitum as BIOSUITED EXAMINERS come down t lines with digital ear thermometers checking temperatures single BEEP means you're okay. A quick triple BEEP-BEEP-B means you're not and prompts a swift response, which we s playing out across the field: Burly MEDTECHS loading the unlucky person into one of the many golf carts on the scene - pulling wives away from husbands, husbands away from wives, children from parents parents from children - a coldly scientific process that with the golf carts speeding the outtakes up the hill to high school while loved ones scream in vain for their ret Here are David and Judy, as stunned and disoriented as everyone else. David confronts a passing examiner, his outrage reflected back at him in the mirrored faceshield.
What did we get exposed to?! What was it?! The examiner walks past without reply. Judy meanwhile appraises the medical teams, the work being done.
Elevated temperature usually means infection, but a toxin can do the same thing... I don't know, the way Peggy was acting makes me think it's chemical.
So they round us up with assault rifles, what's that?
Medical response teams train with case studies, they know the symptomology, pharmacological outcomes --—
In plainspeak.  36.
(looks at him) They're as scared as we are. Judy steps away to help an ASTHMATIC ELDERLY WOMAN who is leaning against the fence. Soldiers escort MAYOR HOBBS an his WIFE onto the field.
Governor Hatfield's a personal friend of mine! Nobody cares. They get dumped in a line near David. Hobbs draws hostile stares. Word of his hasty exodus has apparently gotten around.
Hey Tom, how's Kentucky?
Bastards spiked our tires, pulled us out at gunpoint.
Wow, sounds like your civil rights might have been violated, you should look into that. Hobbs frowns at the sarcasm, taking in the angry stares.
(re: Kentucky) Is that what everybody's so ticked off at me for?
You ran. Town needed a leader.
You be the leader.

It's not our town anymore. David steps to the fence, watches the guards prowling the perimeter. Otherworldly riflemen with biohazard hoods and leashed dogs. His gaze finds the old scoreboard behind th backstop. Lingers on it. Something poignant about it ther behind the barbed wire.
But what he sees past it is chilling. Two figures standin in the tungsten glow of a flood light, staring at him...  37.
Rory's sons. Delirious with rage and vengeance. THEIR FAC

head_text.subj: ARE PARALYZED ON ONE SIDE, RIDDLED WITH SPASMS ON THE OTH

text: Teeth and gums exposed by some obscene tightening of the muscles. A LOUD DULCET TONE on the PA system makes David jump. He looks back and the Hamill boys are gone. Haunted, he scan the dark woods. And suddenly - A HAND grabs his shoulder. He spins, ready for a fight. It’s his deputy.
Funny thing happened on the way to Wichita. Gallows humor. Followed by a deadly serious:
Who are these fuckers?

Same ones who don’t know anything about a dead pilot and aren't missing a plane. David surveys the crowd, sensing beneath the fear and bewilderment a growing rage. It’s palpable, a chemical sh in their psychology.
This don’t end well. David shakes his head - nope. An EXAMINER comes down the line checking temperatures. David engages.
I need to talk to somebody right now! Hey, do you hear me?! The examiner jams a thermometer in David’s ear. Pushes th button. BEEP. Moves on to Judy, who is preoccupied with patient care.
This woman is asthmatic, she needs her medica --
Time stands still. Judy in disbelief. David spins to fend off the onrushing medtechs.  38.
Get away from her! She’s not sick, she’s pregnant! They grab her. David fights, but is hopelessly outnumbere Russell tries to help and is quickly subdued. They drag J away screaming.

You've never seen a man fight like David Dutton fights fo his wife. Zapped with a Tazer gun, kicked, knocked to the ground by a rifle butt, kicked once more. Again and again tries to rise, again and again he is beaten down, until h body no longer answers to his will. Lying in the grass, he lifts his gaze just enough to see being taken up the hill to the high school. By sheer stubbornness, he climbs to his feet once more. Takes a couple of wobbly steps. A gun butt CRACKS him in the back of the head. He goes do and stays there this time. Facedown in the dirt by second base. Expelling one last breath of resistance, her name along with it:
Judy... And then, mercifully, he blacks out.
POV of ceiling lights whipping by above as a masked exami wheels us down the corridor. It's Judy’s POV, strapped to a gurney. The passing classrooms offer flashes of nightmare imagery:

head_text.subj: PEOPLE ON GURNEYS GOING BERZERK. A TEENAGER RACKED BY WIL
TEETH-CLATTERING CONVULSIONS. OTHER PEOPLE SITTING IN

text: Suddenly, right in front of us - A SCREAMING FACE SHATTERS the window of a classroom door, spraying the corridor with shards that CRUNCH as we roll them. A biosuited GUARD beats the screaming man back with baton. Turning the corner, we see  39.

Spanned by rows of sterile-white cots that have not been touched. Unopened boxes of supplies on pallets. Equipment wrapped in plastic. A medical contingency plan abandoned its early stages. As Judy is pushed into a maintenance elevator, an EXAMINE leans over her with an ANESTHESIA MASK. She tries to resi but her arms are strapped and the mask fitted so quickly her face that her scream of protest fogs the plastic.

David awakens in darkness. Lifts his head, disoriented. He’s lying in what appears to be a livestock trailer. Judy. The thought sends him scrambling to the back door. rams it with his shoulder. Pounds it with his fists. Kick it with his boot. His fists again. And as he continues th futile effort to force it open - A DARK FIGURE emerges from the shadows behind him. Creepi closer. Aman. Sinister face catching the light. David, still hammering the door, doesn't see him coming. The figure stops right behind David and we see the grim visage was a trick of the shadows. It's his friend, the concessions vendor from the ball game. KEVIN MILLER.
David... David spins, wild-eyed, caught in a moment of madness.
Kevin! I gotta get outta here! Continues his furious pounding.
(spins again)

You're scaring us. David sees them now. FACES IN SHADOW at the far end, terrified by his erratic behavior. Men, women, children. Faces we recognize from the ball game, the high school, t town meeting. David calms himself, explaining:  40.
They took Judy.

(commiserates ) They took Linda. (indicating other unmatched spouses) And they took George and Francine and Whit and Simon and a whole mess of other people. Breaking your hand on that door's still a dumb idea. David takes his point. Follows Miller back to the group. The townspeople sit huddled together like Third World refugees. A mechanic in a John Deere ball cap (EDWARD) engages David. Frazzled nerves fuel the exchange.
Can't you do something? I mean, Christ -
What do you want me to do, Ed?
Something! You're the sheriff for God's sake!
(as peacemaker; overlapping) Edward --
You're supposed to protect us -- !
(to Edward; overlapping) Hey! HEY!! This ain't helping, Eddie. We're all in the same boat here. Edward simmers down. Feels no real rancor toward David. Just can't handle the situation.
Anybody heard what it is yet? What they spilled? Nobody has.  41.

Whatever it was, they’re keeping us here till it’s cleaned up. Whole town’s sealed off. Roadblocks, everything. Tim Mitchell tried to run one of ‘em, they shot him dead. It’s the guy who gave David the pipeline schematic, here his ten-year-old son. Other children are in tears. Some o the parents as well. A DISTRAUGHT MOM breaks down at the sight of David.
Amy’s out there... my Amy... He embraces her, not knowing what to say. A tall open-fac guy named SHELDON steps forward, local choir director clinging to his faith.
I know things look bad right now, I know they do, but like they say in every tragedy there's a blessing --
(angry) What's our blessing, Sheldon? I'm dying to hear this one.

We're not sick yet. Which means we still got a chance. A blessing indeed. Suddenly, the SQUEAL OF BRAKES. The truck slowing. Lots of NOISE outside. A look of panic sweeps the group. David rips a metal brace from the wall. weapon. The truck STOPS. Parents shield their kids as the door is unlocked. It swings open. SHADOWY FIGURES rush through. David comes at them, ready to attack when he sees they ar RESCUE WORKERS (in less severe biosuits, faces visible) offering bottles of spring water and Powerbars.
Quickly, people. We're getting you out of here.

David and the others step warily from the truck, take in their surroundings. A TRUCKSTOP being used as an operatio staging area. Military trucks refueling.  42. Transport helicopters coming and going from the adjoining field. Supplies and troops being shuttled to and fro. In the fenced-in parking lot where the livestock truck is few HUNDRED SURVIVORS await evacuation, getting treatment first aid tents. A SITE COORDINATOR stands on a military flatbed megaphoning instructions to a LINE OF SURVIVORS b processed for transport:

As you board the buses you will each be given a dispensation card, it looks like this, do not lose it, you will not be allowed into the safe zone without your dispensation card... GREEN PLASTIC BARCODED BRACELETS being snapped on wrists hurriedly scanned into handheld computers. Temperatures taken one last time. Visible relief on people's faces as they look toward the EVACUATION BUSES idling nearby. As David and the others take their place in line, a small miracle. The distraught mom spots her little girl. Bursts into tears -
Hugs her, frantically relieved. The reunion only heighten David's loss. As he surveys the truckstop, plotting his escape:
Don't.
What?
Whatever you're thinking. There's one way out of here and it's on those buses. You got a seat on one. A seat a lot of people wish they had.
Let ‘em have it.
David. This might your last chance. Don’t lose it running off on some fool's errand.  43.
Judy's a fool's errand?
You know what I'm saying.

Tell you what, Kev. You don't ask me why I can't leave without my wife and I won't ask you why you can. A bit harsh but right on the money. Kevin Miller is left nurse his guilty conscience as David takes off. We run with him down the narrow passage between two big r Quick stop. TWO ARMED GUARDS on patrol. David ducks under the trailers, hiding until they’re gone. Moves on. Squeezing through some temporary fencing, he jumps in the back of a SUPPLY TRUCK headed back into town.

SEDATED TOWNSPEOPLE strapped to gurneys in a social studi classroom. Among them we find JUDY, semi-conscious, shove in here amid the overturned desks. An EXAMINER works from field kit, not providing medical care, taking tissue and blood samples. GUNFIRE erupts outside. The examiner stops his work and stares out the window. He doesn’t move. Something terribl is happening out there. Craning her neck, Judy can see

where PANDEMONIUM has broken out. CRAZED TOWNSPEOPLE attacking examiners, murdering medtechs. They overwhelm t guards, shoot them with their own weapons, pull down the fence at center field, causing a stampede.

head_text.subj: ALL THE PRISONERS RUN INTO THE WOODS LIKE LUNATICS FLEEIN

text: ASYLUM. The perimeter soldiers converge and open fire, bu they can’t stop the escape. Seen through the haze of sedation, the horror is dreamlik Judy's eyes flutter closed. Helpless on her gurney. Yesterday’s homework assignment chalked on the blackboard above her.

Sitting among stacks of BOXES, David watches the moonlit prairie go by. Like a practical joke, an old ROAD SIGN go past: "Welcome to Marsh County. Friendliest Place on Earth." David looks at the boxes, curious what’s inside. He opens one. Wishes he hadn't. BODY BAGS.

TICKING clock. Pot of coffee on the coffeemaker. The door CREAKS open. David, crouched like a thief, hurries to his desk, grabs his spare revolver, some bullets. A shotgun f the gun rack. Shells. Loading up, he catches sight of something horrific. Drops box of shells. On the floor of the holding cell - BILL FARNUM HIDEOUSLY CONTORTED IN DEATH. His back arched high off the floor. Neck tendons, obscenely tight, practically tearing the jaw from his face. David steps back, right onto the BARREL OF A SHOTGUN aime his head.
Easy. David raises his arms, turns.
Chief?!
Stop surprising me like that. Manly embrace. David goes to look at Farnum again. Russel obstructs.
Don’t look at that.
They let you guys out?

Let us? People went nuts. Tore the place apart. It was like a human slaughterhouse. I just ran.  45. Sound of a SPEEDING CAR interrupts them. They duck the FL of its headlights. It’s that same BLACK SUBURBAN TEARING PAST THE POLICE STATION at ninety miles an hour.
Judy, man, I tried to stop ‘em. David nods, gathering shells from the floor. Stands, man a mission.
I’m going to get her. Russell doublepumps the shotgun, the stress of the situat bringing out his redneck roots.
Hoo-fuckin'-yah, chief, let's go to the high school.
HYSTERICAL SHRIEKS and SCREAMS fill the school. Violent chaos spilling from the classrooms. An EXAMINER runs down second-floor corridor past a half-dressed LUNATIC roaming halls in a head bandage.
(to staff) Let’s go! Forget it, we're leaving! We are leaving! EXAMINERS scramble for the exits.

The EXAMINER drawing blood samples hears the evacuation order. Grabs his things and runs out, accidentally leavin needle embedded in the last victim’s arm. Blood drips ont the floor. PLIP. PLIP. PLIP. We move up the arm to the face... It’s JUDY. She stares at the dripping blood. Hands strapped, she can do anything to stop it.  46.
EXAMINERS and MEDTECHS jump in helicopters. SOLDIERS into trucks. It’s obvious what’s happening. The military is pulling out, conceding town center to the lunatics.

David and Russell, avoiding the main streets, cut through series of backyards in a dark residential neighborhood. T night reverberates with DISTANT POPS of gunfire. They hop fence and David grabs Russell, pulls him sharply back.
sits at a picnic table in a bathrobe gutting a turkey. Creepy uncomprehending stare. Her HUSBAND noosed from a t behind her.
Did Peter call? Madness. They move on, hop the other fence. The housewife screaming in the b.g. -
As they distance themselves, a look of dread comes to Russell’s face.
That's gonna be me.
You don't know that.
Right out of my goddamn tree like my Uncle Willard who swears on the Bible he ate a tadpole and shat out a bullfrog, and that’s without the screwy water so --
Russ, we got enough problems without you inventing ‘em.
Easy for you to say, you’re at the end of the pipeline. I’m half a mile from the Farnums.  47.
Who's the sheriff?
What?
Who's the sheriff of Marsh County?
You.
I am. Who's the deputy?
Me.
You are. Deputy does what the sheriff tells him, that's the balance of power. Now I'm telling you you're not getting sick, understand? Russell nods, appreciating the sentiment.
Hope you're right, chief. I'm no world beater but I had plans. Crossing a street, they see MILITARY HELICOPTERS, perhaps mile away, lifting off into the night sky. David, alarmed quickens his stride.
That’s the school! They’re bailing! Come on!

PLIP. PLIP. PLIP. Judy watching herself bleed. She could die like this. One drip at a time. Gritting her teeth, pronating her forearm, she manages to painfully scrape th needle from her arm on the side of the gurney. In the aftermath of the military exodus there is an eerie calm filled with SHRIEKS and GROANS, the INSANE RANTINGS the abandoned inmates. With those horrible sounds in her ears Judy scans the classroom. Her fellow townspeople. Varying degrees of madness on display: A middle-aged WOMAN SNICKERING to herself. A teenage BOY BABBLING incoherently.  48. A CATATONIC MAN with the same half dead, half twitching f Bill Farnum had. Others are unconscious, comatose, drooli Judy locks eyes, unexpectedly, with a high school girl strapped down on the other side of the room. Terrified, trembling, but otherwise asymptomatic. BECCA DARLING. Her office helper.
Becca?! Becca, honey, are you hurt...?! Becca, deep in shock, trembling in terror:
Is this... really happening...? Judy puts on a brave face, doctorly instincts taking over
Don’t worry, it’ll be okay. All right?
You don’t really believe that, do you? Becca calls her bluff and suddenly it’s Judy battling emotions. Near tears, she shakes her head no.
Where’s your mom and dad?

We were hiding... we tried to get away... The sentence ends in SOBS. Her parents are dead. Judy tug at her restraints, wants to get over there to help but ca And now they have bigger problems. A terrible sound draws their gazes to the door.

head_text.subj: AN OMINOUS METALLIC SCRAPING NOISE COMING DOWN THE DARK

text: Somebody's coming. You can hear their SHUFFLING STEPS. Ju shoots Becca a look. Be very quiet. Becca stifles her sob as the creepy scraping noise comes CLOSER, CLOSER... And now it stops. The classroom door swings open with a CREAK. A figure silhouetted in the doorway. Image from a nightmare:  49. A pot-bellied LUNATIC drenched in blood. BRUCE WEBBER. Th A & P Manager. He is dragging a PITCHFORK. Judy and Becca watch in mute terror, praying he’1ll leave Instead he enters. Drags the pitchfork to the nearest gur and looks down at the insane snickering woman. He mumbles something nonsensical then raises the pitchfor and SPEARS HER in the chest. Becca SCREAMS. Bruce extract the pitchfork from his first victim and shuffles to his second. The babbling boy. SPEARS HIM and continues his murderous ritual, heading straight for Becca who is thrashing wildly but will never escape. Judy fights to free her hands, to save Becca. She can’t. Stabbing everyone in his path, Bruce arrives at Becca who closes her eyes as the lunatic raises his pitchfork. Just then, Judy from the other side of the room:

The kind of scream even a lunatic can’t ignore. Bruce sto turns. Sees Judy over there, strapped down by the blackboard, helpless. Nudging desks aside, he comes for h instead. Hands pinned at her side, Judy stretches her fingertips j far enough to reach the blackboard chalk tray and, using as a rail, gets the gurney rolling. Rolls herself right o the classroom door, gripping whatever’s within reach. Bruce follows her out, dragging the pitchfork.

Judy rolls down the row of lockers, grabbing the PADLOCKS with that strapped hand, pulling herself along. The SOUND THE PITCHFORK right behind her. Blind panic setting in. H diversion play quickly shaping up as suicide. Craning her neck she can see Bruce coming. Quickens her pace, fingers grabbing frantically at the padlocks. And t tragedy strikes.

misses the next lock, the last one in this row, and as a result she misses the turn. And drifts helplessly into th center of the corridor...  50. The wheels of her gurney CREAK to a stop. Her EYES wide w terror. Her FINGERS still clutching at the air. STRANDED a trophy case of old basketballs. The STEEL PRONGS OF THE PITCHFORK dragging closer. And no
shuffles into view. Stands above her, leering. The ROW OF PADLOCKS swinging behind him like a hundred little pendul As he raises the pitchfork -

Catches him in the arm, spinning him fully around as a SE BLAST RIPS A SIX-INCH HOLE IN HIS CHEST. Bruce Webber fal in a heap, never comprehending his death. David and Russe run to Judy, Russell standing guard as David unstraps her
You okay?
Not really. Unstrapped, she takes off down the hall.
Where are you going?!
Judy unstraps Becca. Becca cries in her arms. Judy holds her as she might her own child.

PREDATORY LUNATICS wander the streets, maimed, bleeding, faces half dead. They attack each other at random, some unleashing the same murderous fury on inanimate objects. predatory types stagger through the night babbling. CRAZE CHILDREN running around like orphans of the apocalypse. David, Judy, Russell and Becca jog along Main Street, pas shattered shopfronts and parked cars that have been BOOTE prevent driving.

Nobody's driving outta here. An APACHE GUNSHIP flies by overhead. Shockingly fast. Shockingly loud. David and the others duck around the cor by the bank. Looks of terror on their faces, knowing they the targets.  51. They run on. Up ahead, a YOUNG MOTHER sits breast-feeding her baby on the curb. She’s sobbing, rocking on her heels Judy slows. David keeps her moving.
It’s Molly Hutchins.
You can’t help her. And we see the baby in the young mother’s arms is not a b A PLASTIC DOLL.
They cross a wide field PULSING with cicadas. A mile from town center it’s almost peaceful. The occasional burst of gunfire in the distance.
That truckstop where fifty hits the county line, they're taking people out of there, putting them on buses.
Where to?
Wichita maybe, wherever, some safe zone.
Hell of a walk, county line.
My cruiser's back at the house.
We'll be sitting ducks on the highway.
I'm thinking the power line road. It's crap, but we can drive it.
Leaves us about a mile on foot.
Exactly.  52. Judy falls behind, stops in the middle of the field. The others look back at her, then to David - what’s going on? walks back to her. She stands, arms folded, trying to hid her fear.
What if they’re right? What if I’m sick? (includes Becca) What if we both are?
You’re not sick.
Saying it doesn’t make it true.

If you're sick, I’m sick -- we drank from the same tap -- and I’m not sick. Not yet anyway. So let's keep walking. They head back to the others, Judy with lingering relucta the issue not entirely settled in her mind.
Wide, flat, glimmering with the same toxic sheen as the b David and the others step carefully from stone to stone.
(to David) See those folks in town? Man oh man, makes you wonder, don’t it? ‘Bout human nature?
It’s not human nature’s doing this, it’s a chemical.
Actin’ on an instinct that’s already there or they’d be group- huggin’ instead of tearing each other apart. Becca slips on a mossy rock and PLUNGES INTO THE STREAM.
Shit! Get her out of there!  53. They pull her out and tend to her on the opposite bank. Becca sits sobbing in the aftermath, scared to death, soa from head to toe.
It’s okay, we’ll get you some dry clothes at the house. Judy shares a private look of concern with David, both noticing the creek’s toxic sheen. Becca sees it, too, and draws her own conclusion.
(shuddering sobs) I’m... gonna... die... Russell takes off his deputy coat and puts it over Becca warmth. Squats in front of her, sheriff-in-the-making.
You're getting out of here. I just made that my duty.
The foursome moves in wary tandem, skirting the perimeter an old farm. A barn. Three silos. Judy walks beside Becca who is cold, shivering, and generally miserable, but mana to strike a lighter note:
Guess this means no prom, huh? Judy half smiles, nods yeah. David's hand flies up, halti the group. He gestures 'stay' then walks on alone a bit farther. Listens. Comes rushing back.

Down down down! They all hit the ground. Hearts pounding. Listening. Davi and Russell draw their guns. David indicates the hillcres And now the enemy comes into view, moonshadowed and letha A PLATOON OF BIOSUITED SOLDIERS wading through the tall g in infrared goggles. One of them is carrying a FLAMETHROW
Oh man.
In there. THREE SILOS behind them. They crawl through the grass.  54.

Close the hatch and watch through RUST HOLES as the soldi storm the farmhouse. We hear a SHRIEK inside the house and moments later the soldiers emerge, dragging a CRYING WOMAN off the porch in the front yard. They stand her up. Somebody jams a digita thermometer in her ear. BEEP-BEEP-BEEP. BANG! They shoot her. Point blank. A battlefield execution. The guy with the FLAMETHROWER steps up and torches the body. David's anger overwhelms his judgement. He reaches for th hatch. Russell grabs his arm - no, chief. Flushed with rage, David tries to pull away, but Russell holds strong. And David's good senses returns. He backs down. But they’ doomed anyway. A SOLDIER IS HEADED OVER TO CHECK THE SILOS. He checks the first then the second, working his way towa the last one, the one they're hiding in. Panic sweeps the group. David searches for some miracle escape. Up. Down. Left. Right. There is nothing. The only exit is
Through the rust holes we see the SOLDIER creeping toward with his assault rifle. Russell readying his weapons. Dav his. Judy in disbelief. Becca whimpering with fright.

(softly) Shut her up! Judy clamps her hand over Becca’s mouth as THE HATCH DOOR CREAKS OPEN. The MUZZLE OF AN M-16 enters first. Then the soldier’s GASMASKED FACE. To the right he sees nothing, to the left RUSSELL who smacks him in the head with his rifle butt, knocking him down. David and Russell drag the semi-consci soldier into the silo and close the hatch.

Pray they don't do a headcount.  55. They wait on pins and needles to see if the missing soldi will be noticed. The platoon regroups in front of the hou and MOVES ON WITHOUT HIM. Gasps of relief. Judy uncovers Becca’s mouth. Becca doubl over crying. Russell yanks off the soldier's helmet, read to crush his skull with the rifle butt. But the face behi the mask is not the face of an enemy... AN EIGHTEEN-YEAR-OLD BOY. Scared as hell. Far from home.
Aw Jesus...

The young private sits against the silo wall, welt on his forehead where Russell smacked him. Blue-collar kid froma blue-collar state. Well-mannered. West Virginia drawl. PVT. BILLY BABCOCK. He's scared. They are the enemy.
What's your name?
Billy Babcock... David gestures to the yard outside, to the execution they just witnessed -- a silent seething ‘why’?
Orders, sir.
From who?!
(shrugs ) Whoever gives ‘em, I dunno. (then) Are y'all gonna shoot me? Judy answers for David and Russell.
No.
Then can you have him stop pointin' that thing?  56. Russell's shotgun aimed at his head. David gives Russell look and Russell lowers it.
Billy, I want you to tell me what exactly the fuck is going on down here.
I dunno. All's they said was there'd been some accident. My whole unit got flown in. We didn't even know what state we was in till we saw the license plates.
There wasn’t anything on the news? Before you left?
No, ma’am. From what I hear they're doing one of them media blackouts. David and Judy exchange a look.
Am I gonna die breathing without my mask?
Is that what they said?
They just said keep it on. Troubled pause. Judy tosses him his gasmask. He straps it on over his face, breathes and talks through it the rest the scene.
Nobody's said anything about what it was they spilled?

No, sir, but -- I’m probably not supposed to talk about this, but my sergeant, he saw this computer program they ran over at central, some kinda 'casualty projection' I think he called it, you know, to see how things were gonna turn out down here.  Gulp. 57.
How'd it go?
Nobody lived past the third day.
Nobody?
Crazies killed most of ‘em, sickness got the rest. Today’s the second day, I’d get out of here tonight if I was you.
How? The truckstop?

Dunno, sir. Perimeter's pretty hardcore. Even for healthies, they're giving ‘em one warning shot then it's a kill order. (then) Look, um, I know I don’t deserve no favors from you people, but if you let me go I swear to God I won’t come back, they can courtmartial me, I don’t care, I didn’t sign up to shoot unarmed civilians. I’11l just leave. Okay...?
Testing the waters, he starts to stand up. Russell levels his gun. David nods
Sit down.
Cool it, Russ.
He'll give away our location.
We're not staying here. ‘go ahead' to the boy. He stands up.
Reckon you're keeping that, huh?  58. His M-16 and AMMO CLIPS.
Yeah, we're gonna hold onto those, Billy. Billy nods okay. Steps to the hatch. Pauses there.
Sorry 'bout your folks's town. Then exits, running off into the night, opposite directio his platoon. David grabs the M-16 and ammo clips.
As they come out the hatch:
Why aren't they telling anybody what’s going on down here? David pauses, Russell’s question hanging.
(indicates) That’s why. THE BURNING CORPSE. They just stare, the firelight playin across their haunted faces.
Let’s get to the house. They set off and we see the farmhouse from a distance. Al on the prairie. A plume of smoke rising up ghostly pale i the moonlight.
They come up through the back acres. David with the M-16 his shoulder. Judy offering a grave assessment.
This wasn’t a chemical spill. (off their looks) They're burning the bodies. It must be bacteriological, viral. Something that spreads by human contact. Or the air.
The air? -- it was in the water.  59. Judy gives a grim nod.
It was. It must have more than one mode of transmission. Or mutated or something, who knows.
(to Judy) How come I’m not crazy yet?
I told you why.
(to Judy) Besides the fact that your husband officially forbade it.
Expose a group of people to something, there’s always a handful who aren’t affected. I don’t know, Russell, maybe you’re naturally immune.

Nah, I’m not that lucky. They walk on. Judy’s face darkens as THEIR HOUSE comes in view at the top of the field. Curtains sway in shattered windows. The cruiser, gutted by fire, smolders in the driveway. Caught up in her emotions, she dashes toward th house with David, Russell and Becca playing catch up.
Judy, wait!
ALTERNATE POV (STATIC) - Through a lace-curtained upstair window, we see them run across the field to the house...

Judy runs in the front door and slows, shocked - THE HOUSE IS DESTROYED. Holes smashed through the walls. Sofas and chairs slashed open. The upright piano decimate David enters and surveys the destruction with Judy as Rus checks the other rooms to make sure there's nobody here.  60. Judy turns and walks out, past Becca who has stopped at t front door out of simple respect. David lingers a moment then follows.
Judy at the clothesline taking down the laundry. David wa over.
What are you doing? (no reply) Stop. He catches her hands. Judy breaks down, dropping clothes. David holds her beside the fluttering white sheets.
(re: house) None of this matters. You know that.

(crying) I don't care about the house... it's everything. Everybody. Everybody we know... I don't see how we recover from this... I don't see how this town ever comes back... Neither does David. He holds her close.
ALTERNATE POV - Through a downstairs window, we see David Judy outside by the clothesline. LOW RASPY BREATHS. Someone, inside the house, is watching.

Judy walks away from the house to clear her head. Becca following, hoping to console. David comes up the steps pa Russell who sits at the top, wiping sweat from his brow w a handkerchief. Russell nods at the smoldering cruiser.
Sheriff-mobile's seen better days.
(nods ) We'll have to take our chances on the highway. Power lines will take too long.  61. Tosses Russell the M-16.
Stay with them, I'll be right back. Russell nods and goes off across the lawn to catch the gi
Overturned appliances. Food spilled on the floor. David grabs some BOTTLED WATER and tosses it in a dufflebag.
With a bowling motion he slides the dufflebag the length the hall to the front door as he heads upstairs.
Cresting the stairs, David comes down the hall to the -
He stops in the doorway, shocked. It’s a bloodbath.
covers two corpses on the bed. Who's under there? David steps closer, draws back the sheet -
Their severed heads on the pillows suggest a husband and wife. David places his hand on a carcass, checking for warmth. His face darkens. Fresh kills. He tenses at a sudden scary thought.

head_text.subj: IS THERE SOMEONE UNDER THE BED

text: He backs slowly away, angling his gaze underneath. BARE FLOOR. A moment of relief and then with renewed dread he slowly turns to face the doorway, realizing the killers are more likely behind him, hiding in the house, perhaps somewhere down this dark upstairs hallway.

David steps into the hall. Tense breath and then he start down it. Very slowly. Trying not to make a sound. Sensitive to the slightest CREAKS of the floorboards.  62. Halfway to the stairs he STOPS ABRUPTLY, thinking he hear something. Listens. Nothing. The house is eerily still. Silent except for the curtains billowing in the broken windows. He continues on. Heel to toe. Heart pounding. Each closed door a potential hiding place. Ten feet in front of him o the left, that door looks particularly suspicious.

open a crack. David’s eyes are riveted to it as he approaches, convinced it will fly open any second. But th attack comes from an open door to his right, from the hal painted nursery. As he passes - A GARBAGE BAG IS YANKED OVER HIS HEAD and he is hit - WHA flat across the chest with a pipe. The blow sends him flying backwards. Bag on his head, Dav is kicked in the gut and dragged into the master bedroom his feet, the plastic sucking back into his mouth as he g for air.
He is thrown across the room into the bureau. CRASH! EXT. DOWN THE ROAD —- CONTINUOUS Judy, walking away, looks back at the house. The windblow grass drowning out b.g. noises.
Did you hear that? Becca shakes her head. Russell too. They walk on.
Staggering to his feet, David claws at the plastic bag covering his face, ripping it away to finally see his attackers.

Faces half paralyzed, half in spasm, wrenched into hideou lopsided sneers. Jake grabs the knife he used to slaughter the pigs and ma a lunging stab. David's hand flies up in a reflexive bloc  63. THE KNIFE POINT COMES OUT THE BACK OF DAVID’S HAND! In and out, a flash of steel. David recoils clutching his hand, blood pouring down. Curt swings a pipe at his head. Barely misses. David stumbles backwards onto the bed, sandwiched between the slaughtered pigs. Jake jumps astride him, drives the knife two-handed at David's chest. David catches him by the wrists, sends him tumbling off the side of the bed, and rolls off the other side as Curt brings the pipe down like a sledgehammer at face. The pipe hits the pillow instead. FEATHERS EXPLODE EVERYWHERE. David climbs to his feet, fumbling for something to fight with. Grabs the phone book. A poor choice. The Hamill boy back him into the corner. Feathers swirling. Curt unleash another swing of the pipe. WHAM! David partly blocks it with the Yellow Pages, but the for sends him flying backwards out the window.
CRASH! - David flies through and tumbles off the porch ro onto the lawn below.
Judy, Becca and Russell whip around.
They run for the house, but they're too far away to help.
David tries to crawl away, but there's no escape. The Ham boys emerge from the house, closing in for the kill.
Russell, Judy and Becca running as fast as they can.

They can't reach him before the Hamill boys do. Knowing this, Russell drops to one knee with his revolver and fir TWO QUICK SHOTS from the neighbor's yard - POP! POP!  64. Dead-centers a round in each of the Hamill boys' chests. slows them but doesn’t stop them completely. Instantly up and running again, Russell puts another two rounds in eac brother on the move - POP-POP! POP-POP! - dropping them i their tracks five feet from David.
Judy runs to David's side, near hysterics. Badly shaken himself, he puts his arm around her. Blood courses down h cheek from his hand.
David oh my God let me see! LET ME
He holds out his hand. Blood pooling in the upturned palm
Oh Jesus, David... She flips it over, sees the exit wound.

...it went through?! He nods yeah, rattled to the core. Becca runs to the clothesline, grabs a T-shirt. Tears off a strip. Ties the first loop around David wrist as a tourniquet and wraps t rest around his palm as a bandage.

Too tight? David shakes his head, it’s fine. Quick thinking by Becca Judy clasps her hand - thanks. This whole time Russell stands over the dead brothers in the b.g. Staring down at them. And then things get WEIRD: He reloads and puts three more bullets in the head of eac brother, slowly, deliberately, savoring each shot. With dawning horror David and Judy watch as he reloads a secon time and continues - BANG! BANG! BANG! BANG! Judy can't watch anymore.
Russell fires one last RESOUNDING SHOT and then, after a pause, walks over and pulls David to his feet, the loyal deputy again.  65.
(seeing David's injury) Still with us?
Yeah. How ‘bout you? Russell catches David’s look and his meaning. Casts a gla at the bodies.
Just making sure. David nods okay. Judy and Becca staring in silence at the two bullet-riddled teenagers on the front lawn.
House in the b.g., the group heads down the road. David a Judy share a private word about Russell who walks just ah the M-16 on his shoulder.
He’s infected.
You don’t know that.
You saw what he did.
He saved my life, that’s what I saw. End of discussion. David lengthens his stride to catch up with Russell.
Arrow-straight to its vanishing point. David, Judy, Becca and Russell come into view. It’s hot and getting hotter. One of those midsummer days where you feel the heat by 10 David stops abruptly.
Goddammit. He turns and looks back the way they came, cursing under breath.
I left the water at the house.  66.
How far to the truckstop?
Fifteen miles.
What do we do? Russell grins at the HOT SUN.
We fry.

Through SHIMMERING HEAT WAVES we see the highway. The foursome in the distance like a mirage. Then in CLOSEUP. Damp shirts. Faces beaded with sweat. Russell takes off his shirt and walks on bare chested. Strong. Sinewy. Humming some 70’s rock song to himself. David watches him, trying to gauge his sanity. Deflects Judy's look of concern with:
I’d worry about her. Indicates Becca, who has fallen behind. Judy goes back, checks on her.
You all right?
I feel sick.
What kind of sick?

Dizzy. Judy takes Becca by the elbow, helping her along. Just th A GUNSHOT splits the silence. David spins, where did that come from? And before the group can orient themselves - ANOTHER GUNSHOT, closer than the first. They dive in the ditch as -
comes four-wheeling across the field.  67.
in blood-soaked hunter vests howling out the windows, fir rifles. Tied down across the hood is the body of
Naked. Gutted like a deer. David and the others stare numbly at this latest horror. The pickup tearing through old barbed wire fence as it races off across the field.
More walking. More sweat. Judy, helping Becca as before, spots a BINGO HALL set back from the highway on a dirt ro An old COUPE DE VILLE parked in the lot.
David. He nods, already spotted it. Russell doesn’t seem to real they've stopped and continues walking.
What about him?
Hey Russ. Russell doesn’t hear him, keeps walking.
Russell! Russell never turns, never slows. David watches, worried.
Where he’s going?
(has no idea) Let’s get the car.

A white peaked-roof bingo hall sits alone on the prairie a church without a steeple. David, Judy and Becca cross t parking lot. A haunting VOICE echoes inside the building, stops them dead in their tracks.
David and Judy trade looks. He cocks his handgun and they continue toward the building.
They enter a carpeted lobby. Framed pictures of happy winners on the wall. And here, a WATER FOUNTAIN. Becca, thirst-crazed, goes straight for it. Steps on the pedal. HISSES and SPUTTERS. No water.
Can't drink it anyway. Becca releases the pedal. And now that haunting voice com over the PA system:
They all look to the set of double doors.

The doors seen from the other side as they open. David, J and Becca stepping through, warily, to scan the dark hall MAN'S VOICE ON P.A. G-47... Standing in the shadows at the far end, under the big illuminated Bingo flashboard, an OLD MAN IN A SHRINER’S H is reading the numbers off ping pong balls as they fly up chute into his hand from an electric blower-tumbler.
(calls to him) That your car out front? No reply, no acknowledgement whatsoever from the old shri He reads another ball.
(over PA system) N-32... They walk up the aisle toward him.
Hey, is that your car out there?
(over PA system) 0-67...  69.
Can we borrow the keys? They stop ten feet away. The old shriner holds out his ha palm downturned, as if to offer David something. A beat t - FSSHHTUNK - a ping pong ball flies up into it.
(over PA system) I-29... Judy spots someone in the shadows. There, sitting among t empty tables on the other side of the room - A MORBIDLY

head_text.subj: OBESE MAN IN SUSPENDERS LEANED INTENTLY OVER HIS BINGO CA

text: She walks over to him, David and Becca close behind.

Excuse me, is that your -- She recoils in horror. The fat man is two days dead. Thro slit. Jaw gaping at his blood-caked Bingo card. They all stand there for a moment processing the image. A five-hundred pound corpse with a Bingo card. Rolls of decomposing fat overhanging the chair he’s sitting in. Ow of the Coupe De Ville? Judy steps closer.
