Holding her breath at the stench, reminding herself she’s doctor, she slips her hand into the dead man’s shirt pock Empty. Right pant pocket. Empty. Left side. Empty. She can’t reach the back ones. He’s sitting on them.
Help me lift him. Startled looks of ‘who us?’ from David and Becca. A look reply from Judy, ‘yes, you two’. They come over and take hold.
On three. One... Two... Three! As they wrestle with the man’s decomposing bulk, the dead weight shifts unexpectedly, slipping -

Shit, get back! The massive corpse goes CRASHING to the floor, the BELLY SPLITTING OPEN on one side unleashing a torrent of blood innards and liquefied fat. Judy stands in that mess, repulsed. Holds up her hand.  70. CAR KEYS.
They exit to find RUSSELL sitting on the bumper of the Co De Ville. Pissed off, pouring sweat, M-16 across his lap.
Guys trying to ditch me?

Russ, I called to ya, you kept walking. We were gonna pick you up down the road. Russell says nothing, dubious. David puts the keys in the ignition. Says a little prayer and gives it a try. The engine turns over twice and STARTS.
Empty highway. The Coupe De Ville comes into view at a cautious thirty miles an hour.
David drives, scanning the horizon for danger. Judy doing the same from the passenger seat. Russell sits bare-chest in the back seat with Becca. Whispers to her, paranoid:
He called to me back there?
Twice.
Loud enough to hear? Becca nods yeah.
Then why didn’t I hear him? Judy shushes everybody.
Listen! They all go silent. And now we hear it, the sound of an oncoming
Oh shit. They’re sitting ducks out here. David punches th gas, spins the tires - SCREEEECH!! A burst of acceleratio followed by a sudden stop as he pulls the car off the roa
- into the wash bay of an automated car wash.

David kills the engine, everybody pitching their ears to fast-approaching ROAR overheard -— VROOOM! - the Apache comes screaming down the highway. Follows the road to its vanishing point. Gone. But the threat remains.
We can’t stay on the highway.
(forced patience) What would you recommend, dear?
You said something about the powerline road.
We're five miles the other way now. Becca, in the back, looks out the window and GASPS. A HIDEOUS HALF-DEAD FACE watching them from the car wash lo
There’s somebody in there.
What? Where?
(pointing) I saw someone. They all stare at the lobby. There’s nobody there.
Let's go. David reaches for the ignition, but before his hand gets there -

head_text.subj: THE CAR WASH ROARS TO LIFE

text: The tracks engage the front tires, yanking the car forwar into the machine.
Holy fuck!
What’s happening?!
Somebody turned it on! An overhead spray nozzle sprays its residual water and th SPUTTERING DRY, pukes PINK LIQUID SOAP all over the windshield, blinding them.

head_text.subj: DAVID, GET US OUT OF HERE

text: He starts the engine, punches the gas, but the tires, cov in pink slime, JUST SPIN in the tracks. They’1l have to r it out.
Goddammit!
Judy catches a glimpse of it through the swirling machine
Over there!! David and Russell spin to look, but their view is obstruc as -
swing into frame, whipping at the windows and body panels flinging the pink soap off in gooey tendrils. And now Bec sees out the back -

She loses it. David whips his head around to see, but the brush comes spinning down off the roof and across the bac window, blinding him. Heightened terror. All the windows covered in soap. The DEAFENING HUM of the MACHINERY. Becca, hysterical, crouch on the floor -

I don’t wanna die like this!  73. A DARK SHAPE zips past Russell’s window. He freaks. Rolls it down and GOES FULLY AUTOMATIC WITH THE M-16, spraying bullets everywhere. David and the others cover their ears the DEAFENING GUNFIRE only adding to the terror.
Crazed, Russell keeps firing, empties the clip. Tosses th spent weapon out the window. Rolls it up again. Turning t tell David:
I saw movement!

EVERYTHING’S FUCKING MOVING!! A momentary calm as the BRUSHES RETRACT. And then - WHAM! - The SWAYING CHAMOIS DRYERS hit the windshield, ma everybody jump. David fires a reflexive shot through the windshield, then steadies himself. The LONG TENTACLES OF FABRIC engulf the car, shimmying ac the windows like living creatures. It’s creepy. God knows what they conceal. David tries the gas again - WHIRRRRRRRR. We hear the tires spinning. David keeps them going, inching the car forward by that small coefficient friction.
Come on, come on, come on... Suddenly, as they clear the tentacles -

The driver’s side window EXPLODES behind David’s head, spraying the interior with glass fragments. Almost simultaneously the rear window EXPLODES, a cinder block landing in the back seat. A LUNATIC FACE flies in at David through his shattered window, teeth bared like a rabid dog. David deflects the bite to the steering wheel where it takes a chunk out of rubber, exposing the steel below. David counters with a vicious elbow that crushes the lunatic’s nose and sends him reeling backwards against th wall. Another LUNATIC walks up onto the hood of the car, holding a cinder block above his head that is destined fo the windshield. Judy screams, shielding her face.  74.

CRASH! The windshield shatters. The car roof caves in as THIRD LUNATIC jumps on top and trampolines. And now the first lunatic is back at the window, a human pit bull, Da barely holding him off by the throat as he starts the eng with his other hand. The first lunatic lashes out, loops a RINSE HOSE around David's neck. A noose. The lunatic on the roof yanks it taut using the overhead swing arm as a winch to pry David of the car. Choking, head jammed against the ceiling, David throws th car into the reverse, creating slack in the hose. Judy frantically unwinds it from his neck. Freed, David goes f throttle. The WHIRRRRRRR of the spinning tires becomes a piercing SCREEEEEEECH as they catch the asphalt at the en the tracks. But at the last second, one of the lunatics loops the hos around BECCA’S NECK As the car peels out, the hose snaps taut and YANKS HER
Judy whips around SCREAMING, jams her foot on the brake.
Jumps out and runs to Becca who is dangling from the swin arm. David and Russell jump out right behind her, droppin the attackers at close range. BANG! BANG! BANG! BANG!

Judy grabs Becca around the torso, supporting her weight she tries to get the hose from around her neck. A despera effort and a futile one. The hose is too tight and BECCA IS DEAD. Neck snapped. Noosed by the high-pressure hose. David comes over, turns Judy away. She fights it and then reality hits. She hammers her fists on his chest in anger and then collapses against him in grief, sobbing. Meanwhile, in the b.g., the Coupe De Ville, left idling i neutral, rolls across the lot and comes to a stop in the road. It sits there idling as Judy returns to Becca now, needing to get her down.  75.

Help me! David pulls his knife and cuts the hose. Becca slumps int Judy's arms. Judy cradles her down into a seated position weeping over the girl’s body. The scene would end on that image, but it’s here that the APACHE revisits them. SCREAMING across the prairie to ope fire on the exposed Coupe De Ville. Bullets strafe the ca lengthwise. It catches fire and burns. They watch in silence. Russell nodding to himself like a reveling in God’s authority. David and Judy's expressions edging toward doom. The smoke, blowing across their faces paints Judy’s tears black.
They walk on. Judy looks ready to give up.
They’1l never let us in without testing us. I already failed that test once.
And you know why.
Oh Jesus, David. Even if you're right, how are we gonna prove it?
I'm feeling persuasive. Up ahead is a FAMILY STATION WAGON stopped by a spike str David checks the ignition as they walk up. KEYS. He reaches in, tries to start the engine.
The tires are flat.
It'll drive on the rims. The engine turns over, won't start. He pops the hood. All the SPARK PLUG CABLES HAVE BEEN CUT.
Bastards.  76. Slams the hood down. Moment of despair. David looks weari down the highway. Hears something behind them. A CAR APPROACHING. There in the distance, coming fast.
Move! They all take cover behind the station wagon. Here it com racing down the highway...
Maybe they'll help.
Did you just block out the last seventy-two hours of your life? They're not even gonna stop.
Sure, they are. With a deranged smile Russell kicks the SPIKE STRIP - bur in the dirt behind the stopped wagon - across the road.

head_text.subj: THE SUBURBAN HITS IT AT A HUNDRED MILES AN HOUR, SKIDS
SIDEWAYS AND GOES INTO A BARREL ROLL.

Russ! Russ! Let me talk to him!  77. Russell mulls it over, gun on the guy’s head. Backs off.
(to Intelligence Officer) What did you people spill? The Intelligence Officer spits blood, looks up at David, dazed, angry.
Who the fuck are you?
The guy standing between you and a bullet. The Intelligence Officer spits more blood then shifts painfully into a seated position. Pulls off the shattered gasmask. Tosses it aside.
What were we exposed to? After a moment, with a sigh of resignation:
Zoonotic agent, rhabdoviridea prototype.
Rhabdoviridea... You mean, rabies?
With a few alterations and enhancements.
What’s he talking about?
(shocked; sickened) A weapon. A biological weapon.
Whoa, whoa, whoa, wait a minute, you guys engineered this crap?! You got any idea what it does to people?!
It does what it was designed to do. Destabilize a population. In this case, the wrong one. (off their stunned looks) (MORE )
MILITARY INTELLIGENCE OFFICER (cont'd) We lost a plane, fellas, what do you want me to say?
How about ‘sorry for destroying your whole goddamn town’?!

Take it up with the pilot, I came down here to help! David has no answer for that. The Intelligence Officer, l Billy Babcock, defies the ‘enemy’ label, just another guy a different side of the issue doing his job.
What’s the incubation period?
Forty-eight hours. After that, you're either dead or you don’t have it. But they’re afraid it could go airborne. It’s rare but it happens and they’re not taking any chances.
How rare?
One-in-a-million.
You guys are gonna let us die here for one-in-a-million odds?

When the risk is global pandemic? You're goddamn right. One carrier is all it takes. Nobody leaves. Grim silence. The Intelligence Officer struggles to his feet, leans wobbly-legged against the wreckage, somebody' husband, somebody's father, the beaten hero of his own st
(apologetic) For what it’s worth, I -- BANG! - his head jerks back as a bullet rips through his forehead. Russell just shot him from behind David.

Nooo!!!  79. Judy is SCREAMING. Falls down as she staggers backwards. Has never seen someone shot at close range. David grabs Russell two-fisted by the shirt and walks him backwards i the field, yelling in his face.
Russell holds David's stare, coldly indifferent.

You talked. Russell shoulders his rifle and walks off, picking up a portable MILITARY RADIO from the debris along the way. Da watches him then helps Judy to her feet. A DEAD INTELLIGENCE OFFICER IN A KANSAS CORNFIELD. Blood, sprayed across the Suburban's undercarriage, SIZZLING on hot exhaust pipe.
David and Judy walk the sun-scorched highway, eyes traine Russell who walks fifty paces in front, a man to fear.
I‘ll get the guns from him.
What if he tries to stop you? Russell, out of earshot, glances back at them as if knowi their private thoughts. Turns forward again. And we get David's reply:
He's a good kid, but I'll kill him if I have to. Russell starts to jog. David and Judy match his stride, maintaining that fifty-pace separation.
Abandoned filling station. Russell crosses the lot and go inside. David and Judy arrive moments later and follow hi Tense. Moment of truth.  80.
David and Judy enter. On the far wall is a cooler filled with BOTTLED WATER. Russell tosses them both a bottle.

Thanks. Russell exits without a word. Steps outside and pours an entire bottle over his head. Opens a second bottle and si down drinking it on the concrete median by the pumps. David and Judy guzzle, the excess water running down thei necks. Both watching Russell through the window as he SCA THE CHANNELS on the military radio. STATIC. He puts the radio down and heads for the men’s room. David sees Russell’s mistake. The radio, and HIS GUNS, sitting by the pumps.

Russell, at the urinal, flushes, zips, steps to the sink where he blows his nose into his handkerchief. THE WHITE CLOTH TURNS DARK RED, FILLING WITH BLOOD. He tucks it away, seemingly unaware. Stares at himself in the cracked mirror. Dead-eyed. Sweat rivering down his cheeks. Madness.
Russell exits. Sees his guns are gone. Flushing with rage he crosses to David, who has them.
I'm gonna need those back.
I'll carry 'em for a while. You've been carrying 'em the whole time.
Yeah, thanks anyway. Russell reaches for them. David shakes his head, stony.
I got ‘em.  81.
You sure about that?
Yeah. Russell nods, nods again, then draws from behind his back SPARE HANDGUN. David is hopelessly outdrawn. Judy white with terror.
Russell, we're on your side...
My side? I didn't even know there was sides.
There's not, I didn't --
Tell her to shut up. David gestures. Judy stops talking. Russell presses the g to David's chest.

One.. (taps him again) Two... (taps him again) Three! You're waiting for the gunshot but Russell just shakes hi head in reproach.  82.
That's how many times I saved your life.
Russell, who now has all the guns, gestures down the road with his revolver.
(e.g. ‘walk’) Out in front where I can see you. David and Judy start down the road, Russell behind them. They talk under their breath.
Let's just run.
No. Give him a target he'll hit it. Let me think a minute. They walk on, weighing their options. And David realizes. They have none.
(turns) Fuck it, I'm gonna confront him.
David, no -
We don't get to that truck stop we're dead anyway. He walks back toward Russell. Russell raises the M-16.
Back off.

Russell takes aim at David's face.
Just wanna talk.  83.
Put the gun down. Russell tightens on the trigger.
You better listen to me.
Put it down.
I just want to talk to you. David walks right up to him. The M-16 pointed at his thro Russell staring down the barrel.
Can we talk? Man to man? A long tense moment then Russell lowers his weapon.
Okay. Here's the deal -- David PUNCHES HIM square in the face, lays him out flat. Russell, dazed, offers no resistance as David quietly dis him, just stares at the sky like he's daydreaming:
(hazy) Remember that monster catfish I caught last summer?
(disarming him) Yeah.
(hazy) What'd he weigh, you reckon?
(disarming him) Ten fifteen pounds.  84. Faint smile from Russell.
(hazy) Big son of a bitch. Judy arrives, her shadow falling across Russell who sits now, semi-lucid, the suckerpunch helping clear his head.
I'm not right, am I? David shakes his head no. Russell nods in confirmation. Unexpectedly, his voice cracks with emotion.
Can I keep walking with you guys? Little while longer? David trades looks with Judy.

They're jogging again. Russell struggling to keep up. Jud drinks from a water bottle, passes it to David. He finish it, tosses it. And before the bottle hits the ground - he grabs her and pull her into the tall grass. They peer through it. Both crouching. TWO MILITARY TRUCKS butted together form a CHECKPOINT two hundred yards down the road. SIX HEAVILY ARMED SOLDIERS I BIOSUITS. No way past. Russell arrives beside them, huffing. Sizes up the checkpoint. Indicates a route through the adjoining field
Cut through there, you can pick up the highway on the other side.
They'll see us.
They'll be focusin' on me. David looks at Russell. He's offering to sacrifice himsel
Deputy does what the sheriff tells him. You're the sheriff. Permission. David can't give it. Russell holds out his ha for a gun.  85.

I’m done, chief, let me go out big. Moment of deliberation then David puts the revolver in Russell’s hand, making sure it's fully loaded. A beat and then he gives him the shotgun as well, pumping his last shells into the chamber. Gun in each hand, Russell eyes t checkpoint. Steeling himself. Looks at David one last tim

Hoo-fuckin'-yah. And takes off through the field toward the checkpoint. We run with him, immersed in the sounds - the SWISHING GRASS his POUNDING STEPS, and the ROCK ANTHEM he's singing unde his breath to psych himself up ("Walk This Way"):

Met a cheerleader was a real young bleeder oh the times I could reminisce, 'Cause the best things of lovin' with her sister and her cousin only started with a little kiss, like this... He OPENS FIRE, veering out of the field in a dead sprint the checkpoint. Takes out four of the six soldiers before they gun him down. The remaining soldiers gather around Russell's body. Davi and Judy running to safety through the opposite field.
A road sign. Quik Phil's Truckstop 1/2 MILE. David and Ju lengthen their strides.
Come on. We're there.

David and Judy slow as they reach the parking lot, anticipation turning to dread. THE TRUCKSTOP IS ABANDONED. A ghost town. They kick aside the temporary fencing and w across the empty parking lot. It's strewn with litter lik state fairground at the end of the season.
It was Grand Central last night.  86.
They must have gotten everybody out.

In what...? The EVACUATION BUSES are parked in the same spot as befor And booted, like the cars in town, to prevent driving. It eerily quiet. Which makes the one sound they do hear all more ominous. A STEADY HUM from the far side of the parking lot where T REFRIGERATED BIG RIG TRAILERS ARE LINED UP. David and Judy exchange a grim look.
Seventy-footers. Back doors padlocked. Refrigeration unit HUMMING. David breaks open a padlock using the shotgun as pry arm. Swings open the door...

They weren't even sick... David picks something up off the ground. A HANDFUL OF M-16 SHELL CASINGS.

A trash can SHATTERS the glass door. David and Judy step through and survey the deserted truckstop. Slot machines glimmer multi-colored in the darkness.
David and Judy lean over a KANSAS MAP in the empty restaurant. The soft HISS of static on the military radio  87.
We don't get outta here nobody's ever gonna know what happened.
They wiped out an entire town. What are they going to say?
Whatever they want. (indicates map) All these roads are gonna be blocked.

They grab supplies. Bottled water. Chocolate bars. Hats and sunglasses from a display rack as they exit. INT. CORRIDOR, QUICK PHIL’S TRUCKSTOP - CONTINUOUS Come down the hall toward the main entrance.

Thirty miles to Wichita. On foot, avoiding main roads, we’ll average maybe three four miles an hour. That gets us there by daybreak. A NOISE stops them. Came from just around the corner. Sitting in one of those private pay phone stalls with his back to us is a beast of a man, a giant Oklahoma TRUCK DR in a blood-stained tanktop. The blood is his own, seeping from a gunshot he took in the chest and didn’t die from. David ducks back around the corner. Holy shit. He turns back to Judy, motioning for her to head back the opposite direction. But just then we hear -

The COIN spinning faster and faster. The truck driver's FOOTSTEPS approaching. He comes around the corner, looks up from the coin at Dav and Judy. His face is grotesque:

driven by the THIRD HUNTER, pulls up right outside the windows, the back of it heaped with bodies. David and Jud flat on their stomachs, draw quick terrified breaths.
Did he see us?

I don’t know. We gotta move. They crawl across the carpet toward the far side of the restaurant. The two hunters drag the dead truckdriver out by his ankl and heave his body up onto the pile. text: guffawing, guns leveled, looking for prey.
Fuck. David ducks down. Scans the kitchen. No visible exits. They’re trapped.

Where are they? David gestures ‘right there, shhhhh.’ He peers through th crack in the door, watching as: The hunters search the restaurant, looking under tables, working their way through the seating area toward the kitchen. One of them slips out of view as they approach.

They're coming. David and Judy retreat toward the back of the kitchen. Da grabs a couple of knives as they pass the cook’s station, hands one to Judy. They hide around a corner, flatten themselves against the wall, David with a finger to his l telling Judy not to make a sound. And now -
swing open. The two hunters enter. We hear their heavy bootsteps. The treads leaving bloody footprints on the tiles. They make their way past the cook’s station and th sink to

ten feet away. Fire exit. Can they make it? He motions to Judy. They go for it. Slip through.

The hunters in hot pursuit, galloping along in their bloody boots.
David and Judy cut through an arcade. Pinball machines an slot machines flying past in a blur. BOOM! - a shotgun bl vaporizes a Pacman machine.
They exit the arcade into a hallway with one flickering fluorescent light. David grabs door handles as they run, looking for an exit. This one opens.
Shit. They run on. Desperate. GUNSHOTS chasing them aroun the corners. The hunters closing in. Nowhere to run. Except this -—
David yanks it open. He and Judy race through, down a
gl. lined with vending machines and chairs that widens into a lobby of some sort.
Flies open. David and Judy, charging through, find themselves in -
The cavernous work area where they service the rigs. Davi locks the door behind them. A temporary respite because a
looks in from the lobby. As soon as they see it, the two hunters are there. David spins, sees:

Climb! Scaling tool chests and oil drums, David and Judy climb u the elevated truck cab as -

text: David and Judy dive inside the cab as shotgun blasts pulverize the doors. The hunters keep shooting, emptying their guns at the elevated rig. When they stop to reload
David and Judy, crouched on the floor, seize the moment.
Lock ‘em! They both lock their doors and crouch back down, bracing themselves for another assault. But there are no more gunshots. Not yet. What they hear instead are TOOLS SPILLING TO THE FLOOR.

Oh my God, they’re climbing up! David jumps into the driver’s seat as the FIRST HUNTER CL INTO VIEW. He meets David's gaze with a murderous grin. Aims his shotgun at the glass.  92. David kicks his door open, sending the hunter flying off the floor below where his SKULL HITS with a SICKENING CRA Undeterred, he starts climbing back up. The SECOND HUNTER scaling the tool chests ahead of him. But David sees something far more terrifying than these t

climbs in through the lobby window. Knife still embedded his neck, blood rivering from the wound, he glares up at David in the truck then starts looking around for somethi Sees it over there on the wall.
David reads his intention, tosses Judy the keys. No time waste.

See if any of those work! Judy starts trying them in the ignition, one after anothe tossing the useless sets aside. The Third Hunter could just press the release button, but decides to shoot it instead. Blows the entire switch assembly off the wall. THE RIG DOESN’T MOVE. So the Third Hunter walks over under the truck and starts firing randomly into the sub-floor mechanics of the lift itself. He finally hits some vital part, not anticipating the outcome -— WITH A HYDRAULIC WHOOSH THE BIG RIG DROPS STRAIGHT DOWN. Judy SCREAMING in freefall. WHAM! - THE RIG LANDS, CRUSHING the THIRD HUNTER UNDERNEA The other two hunters find this mishap hilarious, LAUGH UPROARIOUSLY. A strange interlude. Judy desperately fishi around on the floor.
What are you doing?!
I dropped the keys! David bends to help. Something hits the windshield like a sledgehammer.  93.

text: Devastating blows. Each impact WHITENS THE GLASS, sending pebbled fragments flying back at David’s and Judy's faces Judy trying whatever keys she can find.
None of them work! WHAM! More pebbled fragments flying back at them. Judy, ducking it, fishes around on the floor for more keys. Fin another set. Tries them. No good.
Hurry!
I can't find them! Fishes around under the seat. Finds another set. Jams the in the ignition and

text: David lets out a howl.
Throws the rig into gear and with the AIRHORN BLARING -
COMES CRASHING OUT through the garage door. The rig tears off across the parking lot with the redneck hunters staggering after it on foot.
Speeding down the highway. Pulses pounding. Judy unfolds map from the glovebox.
The smallest straightest road to Wichita.
Perfect.  94.
The truck races down a country lane, a big moonlit dust c rising in its wake.
Judy fiddles with the MILITARY RADIO, picks up a STATICKY SIGNAL.
What was that? She fiddles some more. Snippets of MILITARY COMMUNICATION becoming audible through the STATIC:
...Fifty-nine... (STATIC)
...fifty-five...fifty-four... (STATIC)
...fifty-one...fifty... Judy and David turn slowly to look at one another. Haunte by the same question.
What happens at zero? David floors the gas pedal.
...forty-five...forty-four... (STATIC)
...forty-two...
The truck barrels toward us down the quiet country road.
...-thirty-six...thirty-five...
David and Judy race on, rigid with fear. The dark countryside shooting past the windows.
..-thirty...twenty-nine...twenty- eight... Judy scrambles into the sleeper compartment, watching out back window.  95.
...twenty...nineteen...eighteen... seventeen...sixteen... JUDY'S POV - The road receding toward the black horizon.
(pedal to floor) That's everything!
The WILD WHITE EYES of frightened horses jumping back fro roadside fence as the truck flies past.
...twelve...eleven...
David's white-knuckled grip on the wheel. Judy's face pressed against the back window. That ominous STATIC-LACE VOICE on the radio:
...ten...nine...eight... The road flying toward us out of darkness.
...five... David's face.
..-four... Judy’s face.
...three... Judy reaching over, gripping David's shoulder.
«+.two... David gripping her hand.
...one...  96. Zero. Judy staring out. David craning his neck.
Anything? Judy silent, waiting, staring.
Anything?!
No...
Nothing? Just the black horizon. Judy, baffled, meets eyes with Da in the rear view mirror.
Nothing. And then it hits.

text: Searing white light fills the cab. Judy watching the blas through her fingers.
Oh my God...
David, bone-chilled, looks out his side window, sees —

text: sweeping over eerily backlit barns and houses.
The shockwave wallops the truck like a punch from God, pitching it forward on the front axle.
Through the windshield we see the shockwave go shooting p us down the highway, Mach One, its vacuum sucking out the rig's side windows - BOOSH!  97.
The truck falls back onto its rear wheels, SNAPPING THE R AXLE.

David wrestles the rig under control, steers it onto the shoulder, the axle GRINDING ON PAVEMENT. The initial blinding burst dims to an EERIE CRIMSON HALFLIGHT and we the aftermath, a NETHERWORLD of fire and smoke and swirli ashes: A mile-wide CORNFIELD engulfed in flames. The POSTS OF A WOODEN FENCE like a row of torches. A hellish BLACK-ORANG MUSHROOM CLOUD rising up from the prairie beyond. David and Judy stare in speechless horror. STATIC crackli on the military radio like the countdown never happened.
David and Judy trudge through waist-high grass. Sun pinkening the sky in the east. Wichita on the near horizo Looks of hope.
People. Traffic. Life as normal. David and Judy walk up a commercial street in the trucker hats and sunglasses they took from Quik Phil’s.

Greasy spoon. Full of PATRONS. David sits at the counter his trucker hat and sunglasses. Quiet. Inconspicuous. Jud is on the pay phone in the back. She hangs up, comes over and sits on the stool beside David.
My parents are coming to get us. David holds his reply as the waitress steps up, pen poise take their order.
What'1ll it be?
Couple waters.
That it?  98. He nods, catches her hand as she turns.
Bottled. She nods okay. On a tv above the counter, regular programming is interrupted by a SPECIAL NEWS UPDATE. Patr look up from their meals with the concern one feels for a neighboring community.

Casualties continue to mount following a devastating explosion at a chemical plant in rural Kansas. Ogden Marsh, a farming community of some four hundred families, is believed to have been leveled in the blast. Authorities continue to search for survivors, but hold out little hope. More as this tragic story unfolds... The official version of events. David watches in disgust. Judy in disbelief, stating the obvious:

That’s not what happened. The waitress brings the waters and the check. As David reaches for the bottles, he pauses, noticing something. There, on the check, by the waitress's smiley-face signature...
Strange. Like ink from a broken pen. He lifts his sunglasses and the spot turns it's natural color:
Disbelief. He touches his fingers to his nose. They come back dripping. Judy sees the blood. Her look of horror is our final image.
No... FADE OUT.
